ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I learned how to analyze and compare historical texts. I also learned about some of the foundational political philosophies of the western tradition.
I learned how to write an essay on a very narrow topic, grounded in the text. I learned how to (kind of) deal with seemingly insurmountable piles of reading, participate in seminar.
How to think about historical connections and distinguish between different political theories.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
Strengths: Professor Nakhimovsky was definitely a strength of the course. He helped guide really interesting seminar discussions and would always challenge our viewpoints to make us think more deeply. I also really liked the texts for the course. 
Weaknesses: The lectures were usually very insightful and helpful but sometimes they felt tangential.
The strengths included the readings we were assigned, class discussions, and the essay prompts.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: I would definitely recommend this course to anyone interested in the foundations of western political thought or someone who wants to learn how to think about history. Also if you can take the class with professor Nakhimovsky I definitely would.
Yes! I loved DS H&P, particularly the work of all the historians.
